The following is the key result of this Section.

Key Point

Any symmetric matrix \(A\) can be diagonalized using an orthogonal modal matrix \(P\) via the transformation \[ P^TAP = D = \left[\begin{array}{cccc}\lambda_1 & 0 & \cdots & 0\\ 0 & \lambda_2 & \cdots & 0\\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \\ 0 & 0 & & \lambda_n\end{array}\right]. \] It follows that any \(n\times n\) symmetric matrix must possess \(n\) mutually orthogonal eigenvectors even if some of the eigenvalues are repeated.

It should be clear to the reader that the above Key Point is a very powerful result for any applications that involve diagonalization of a symmetric matrix. Further, if we do need to find the inverse of \(P\), then this is a trivial process since \(P^{-1}=P^T\) (the previous Key Point).
